description.narrative: Sustainable access to safe water has become problematic in Syria because of a multitude of reasons: first, as a result of the conflict, the water infrastructure has been either completely destroyed or damaged and the relevant Local Water Establishments (LWEs) do not have the required material /spare parts to repair and access to site to provide regular maintenance of the already damaged infrastructure; second, as a result of the sanctions placed on the country, there is a shortage of fuel required to generate electricity and water pumping stations. For most water systems to function efficiently, pumping stations need a pumping time of at least 20 hours a day in order to fill the tanks and supply sufficient water to the governorates. Many times water systems are unable to provide water in adequate quantities, leading to water shortages, rendering the communities, in particular women and children, to either go out of their homes to search for water which as a consequence can lead to numerous protection issues, or being forced to spend a major chunk of their meagre income or savings on purchasing water. It is estimated that 80% of water infrastructure in Syria is now in need of rehabilitation and maintenance . Lack of availability of fuel and hence electricity shortages mean that water pumping stations cannot operate at their full potential; the lack of Operation and Maintenance (O<(>&<)>M) material and timely availability of spare parts and contingency materials mean that adequate repair for the water infrastructure also cannot be conducted. Oxfam’s WASH interventions in Syria include Homs, Hama, Idleb, Aleppo, Quneitra, Sweida, Daraa, Tartous, Damascus and Rural Damascus. The interventions implemented ranged from water trucking, rehabilitation and development of water sources such as equipping wells, drilling, repairs, and water treatment to support of operations and maintenance, hygiene kits distribution, and awareness campaigns. Oxfam in Syria has accumulated capacity to run the projects backed by regionaland global support teams with extensive experience, expertise and knowledge of the region. This project is aimed at Pre-Positioning for Essential WASH NFIs for Immediate Life-Saving Response in Syria during the period of 3 months from January to March 2016 with a total budget of € 1.422.000,-. The project will be implemented in Damascus, Rural Damascus, Aleppo, Homs, Hama, Sweida, Quneitra, Tartous, Daraa in Syria (as needs dictate) Planned number of beneficiaries (men/women <(>&<)> total no. of households): 190.000.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Great Britain is a member of Oxfam International, a confederation of independent national organisations working in more than 90 countries. Oxfam works on six goals that support the shared vision of a just world without poverty: help people claim their right to a better life; champion equal rights for women; saving lives, now and in the future; safeguard global food supplies; help people claim a fairer share of natural resources; and increase money for basic services. For 70 years, Oxfam has been running emergency responses, development projects and campaigning at the grass roots level to tackle poverty.
